title: BP Intensifies Cost-Cutting Amid Declining Profits
summary: BP reported a decline in annual profits to $7.5 billion in 2025, down from $8.9 billion the previous year, primarily due to a 20% drop in crude oil prices. In response, the company has escalated its cost-cutting measures, increasing its target to achieve savings of $5.5 billion to $6.5 billion by the end of 2027, up from a previous goal of up to $5 billion. BP has suspended its share buyback program and is reducing spending to strengthen its financial position, including selling a 65% stake in its Castrol business. The company is shifting strategy away from renewable energy investments to refocus on core oil and gas operations, a move expected to continue under new CEO Meg O'Neill, who will be the first woman to lead a major global oil firm. BP faces pressure from shareholders for underperforming compared to rivals and is tackling a debt of about $22 billion. Profits in the final quarter fell 30% to $1.54 billion as Brent crude oil prices dipped below $60 a barrel, marking the third consecutive year of declining profits, which peaked at $27.7 billion in 2022 during high oil prices after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Rival Shell also reported a profit drop, indicating industry-wide challenges.

background_read: BP is a multinational oil and gas company, one of the world's largest, involved in exploration, production, refining, and distribution. The oil industry is highly sensitive to global crude oil prices, which fluctuate based on supply, demand, and geopolitical events like conflicts. Companies like BP often use strategies such as cost-cutting, asset sales, and share buybacks to manage financial performance during downturns. Shareholders, who own parts of the company, can pressure management to improve returns, especially when rivals outperform. Debt management is crucial for corporate stability, and leadership changes, like appointing a new CEO, can signal strategic shifts, such as moving away from renewable energy investments to prioritize profitable core operations in a challenging market.
